question: Question_01_(a)
statement:
Evaluate

\[\displaystyle
\lim_{x\to 1}{\frac{x^2+2x-3}{x-1}}\] Or determine that this limit does
not exist.
sols:
Directly plugging in \emph{x}=1 into the limit gives 0/0. We try to
factor to cancel out the terms making the fraction zero.

\begin{align*}
&\lim_{x\to 1}{\frac{x^2+2x-3}{x-1}}\\
=&\lim_{x\to 1}{\frac{(x-1)(x+3)}{x-1}}\\
=&\lim_{x\to 1}(x+3)\\
=& (1) + 3\\
=&4
\end{align*}

Directly plugging in \emph{x}=1 into the limit gives 0/0. Since this is
an indeterminate form, we can use L'Hospital's rule:

\begin{align*}
&\lim_{x\to 1}{\frac{x^2+2x-3}{x-1}}\\
=&\lim_{x\to 1}{\frac{(x^2+2x-3)'}{(x-1)'}}\\
=&\lim_{x\to 1}{\frac{2x+2}{1}}\\
=&\lim_{x\to 1}{2x+2}\\
=&2(1)+2\\
=&4
\end{align*}
hints:
The first step to evaluating a limit is to plug in the value you are
limiting to, in this case \emph{x}=1. This will fail - can you
manipulate the numerator and the denominator to handle why it fails?
